statement: Begins to engage in parallel play (playing next to but not directly involved in another child's play)
Participates in associative play (playing independently but engaging in the same activity as other children, sometimes interacting through talking or sharing toys)
Engages in cooperative play with peers (communicates and collaborates with other children in role play or to achieve a goal)
Shows increasing understanding and demonstration of social skills such as turn-taking, initiating and joining in group play situations, and solving social conflict with adult guidance

statement: Forms trusting relationships with nurturing adults
Engages in back-and-forth interactions with familiar adults (e.g., peek-a-boo, makes vocalizations in response to adult interaction, imitates facial expressions or sounds)
Participates in longer back-and-forth interactions with adults to share experiences; imitates adults' actions; communicates ideas; seeks distance; and engages in role play, games, or other activities
Takes greater initiative in social interactions and begins to show interest in familiar adults' feelings, preferences, and well-being

Looks to particular people for security comfort and protection and shows distress or uneasiness when separated from a special person (separation anxiety) or when encountering strangers (stranger anxiety)
Separates from primary caregivers with minimal distress when with other familiar and trusted adults*
